meanings.definition: To revoke or take back a gift or bequest.
meanings.sent1: She decided to adeem the present she had given to her friend.
meanings.sent2: The man had to adeem the inheritance due to unforeseen circumstances.
meanings.sent3: The magician adeemed the rabbit out of the hat, much to the audience's surprise.
meanings.sent4: The storm seemed to adeem all the joy from the sunny day.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's red pen seemed to adeem all the mistakes on the student's paper.

meanings.definition: To disown or deny a relationship with someone.
meanings.sent1: He chose to adeem his brother after their argument.
meanings.sent2: The celebrity decided to adeem any association with the scandal.
meanings.sent3: The cat playfully adeemed the toy mouse, pretending not to know it.
meanings.sent4: The shadows of the night seemed to adeem any familiarity in the dark alley.
meanings.sent5: The cold silence between them seemed to adeem any past friendship.

meanings.definition: To cancel or annul a legal document.
meanings.sent1: The lawyer had to adeem the contract due to a mistake in the wording.
meanings.sent2: The judge decided to adeem the marriage certificate after discovering fraud.
meanings.sent3: The computer virus seemed to adeem all the important files on the hard drive.
meanings.sent4: The heavy rain threatened to adeem the ink on the paper.
meanings.sent5: The eraser seemed to adeem the pencil marks effortlessly.
